revision.text:
{{featured article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox military person |name= Robert Henry Maxwell (Bobby) Gibbes |birth_date= 6 May 1916 |death_date= {{death date and age|2007|4|11|1916|5|6|df=yes}} |birth_place= [[Young, New South Wales|Young]], New South Wales |death_place= [[Sydney]], New South Wales |image= Bobby Gibbes 1942 (AWM 011962).jpg |alt=Informal head-and-shoulders portrait of grinning man with light beard and gap in teeth |caption= Bobby Gibbes, North Africa, c. January 1942 |nickname= |allegiance= Australia |serviceyears= 1940–46
1952–57 |rank= [[Wing Commander (rank)|Wing Commander]] |branch= [[Royal Australian Air Force]] |commands= [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|No. 3 Squadron]] (1942–43) |unit=[[No. 23 Squadron RAAF|No. 23 Squadron]] (1940)
[[No. 450 Squadron RAAF|No. 450 Squadron]] (1941)
[[No. 2 Operational Conversion Unit RAAF|No. 2 OTU]] (1944)
[[No. 80 Wing RAAF|No. 80 Wing]] (1944–45) |battles= World War II *[[Mediterranean and Middle East theatre of World War II|Middle Eastern theatre]] **[[Syria–Lebanon Campaign]] **[[Western Desert Campaign]] *[[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific theatre]] |awards= [[Distinguished Service Order]]
[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross and Bar]]
[[Medal of the Order of Australia]] |laterwork=Businessman }} '''Robert Henry Maxwell (Bobby) Gibbes''', [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]], [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|DFC]] and [[medal bar|Bar]], [[Order of Australia|OAM]] (6 May 1916 – 11 April 2007) was a leading Australian [[flying ace|fighter ace]] of World War II, and the longest-serving wartime commanding officer of [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF]]. He was officially credited with 10¼ aerial victories, although his score is often reported as 12, including two shared. Gibbes was also credited with five aircraft probably destroyed, and a further 16 damaged. He commanded No. 3 Squadron in North Africa from February 1942 to April 1943, apart from a brief period when he was injured. Born in rural [[New South Wales]], Gibbes worked as a [[Jackaroo (trainee)|jackaroo]] and salesman before joining the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] in February 1940. Posted to the [[Mediterranean and Middle East Theatre|Middle East]] in April 1941, he flew with No. 3 Squadron in the [[Syria–Lebanon Campaign]], and became commanding officer during the [[Western Desert Campaign]], where his leadership and fighting skills earned him the [[Distinguished Service Order]] and the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross and Bar]]. Subsequently posted to the [[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific]], he served with [[No. 80 Wing RAAF|No. 80 Wing]] of the [[Australian First Tactical Air Force]], and took part in the "[[Morotai Mutiny]]" of April 1945. After the war he spent many years in New Guinea developing local industry, for which he was awarded the [[Medal of the Order of Australia]] in 2004. He continued to fly until the age of 85, and died five years later in 2007. ==Family and early career== The only son of Henry and Cora Gibbes, Robert Henry Maxwell (Bobby) Gibbes was born on 6 May 1916 in [[Young, New South Wales|Young]], New South Wales.{{cite news |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/78449829 |title=The "Fighting Gibbes" of the RAAF |newspaper=[[Daily News (Perth, Western Australia)|Daily News]] |location=Perth |date=30 July 1943 |accessdate=18 September 2013 |page=5 |publisher=[[National Library of Australia]]}}Chisholm, ''[[Who's Who in Australia]] 1947'', p. 361 He came from a family that had long been active in the government and military. His great-grandfather, Colonel [[John George Nathaniel Gibbes]], built his residence "Wotonga" at [[Kirribilli, New South Wales|Kirribilli]]; the property was later refurbished to become Sydney's [[Admiralty House, Sydney|Admiralty House]]. Gibbes' grandfather, Augustus Onslow Manby Gibbes, owned [[Government House, Canberra|Yarralumla]] station, subsequently the official residence of Australia's [[Governor-General]].{{cite web | last=Humpherson |first=Andrew|date = 3 June 2004 | title = Tribute to Mr Bobby Gibbes| work= Hansard & Papers | publisher=Parliament of NSW |url=http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/parlment/hansart.nsf/5f584b237987507aca256d09008051f3/c1bf5c8d8059c852ca256eb300362429!OpenDocument| accessdate = 20 October 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060212153148/http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/parlment/hansart.nsf/5f584b237987507aca256d09008051f3/c1bf5c8d8059c852ca256eb300362429!OpenDocument |archivedate = 12 February 2006}}{{cite web | last=Dulhunty|first=Beryl|year = 1959 | title = The Dulhunty Papers: Chronicle of a Family| url=http://www.dulhunty.com/html/Dpc11.htm| accessdate = 20 October 2007| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070828205409/http://www.dulhunty.com/html/Dpc11.htm| archivedate=28 August 2007}} His father was a [[Station (Australian agriculture)|grazier]] and his uncle Fred a [[Sopwith Camel]] pilot in World War I who was killed in action.Gibbes; Stokes, "Gibbes, Robert Henry Maxwell 'Bobby'", p. 5 Gibbes attended [[All Saints College, Bathurst|All Saints College]] in [[Bathurst, New South Wales|Bathurst]], and various schools in [[Manly, New South Wales|Manly]], before earning a living as a [[Jackaroo (trainee)|jackaroo]].{{cite journal | last = Carman | first = Gerry | date = 14 April 2007 | title = Air ace was born to fly: Bobby Gibbes 1916–2007 | url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/obituaries/air-ace-was-born-to-fly/2007/04/13/1175971342951.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1 | journal = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | accessdate = 26 October 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022182058/http://www.smh.com.au/news/obituaries/air-ace-was-born-to-fly/2007/04/13/1175971342951.html?page=fullpage|archivedate=22 October 2012}}Gibbes; Stokes, "Gibbes, Robert Henry Maxwell 'Bobby'", p. 3 Gibbes was working as a salesman when he joined the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) on 2 February 1940.Garrisson, ''Australian Fighter Aces'', p. 133{{cite web|url=http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?serviceId=R&veteranId=1204688|title= Gibbes, Robert Henry Maxwell|publisher=World War 2 Nominal Roll|accessdate= 4 August 2013}} He exaggerated his height, which was below the minimum requirement, to gain entrance. In a 1990 interview, he related that he had undertaken flying lessons at his own expense prior to enlisting, but "when war was declared, I thought I'd wait for [[George VI|King George]] to pay for the rest". He further recalled that he applied to join the [[Royal Australian Navy]] at the same time, but was still waiting for a response.Gibbes; Stokes, "Gibbes, Robert Henry Maxwell 'Bobby'", pp. 3–4 After completing flying training at [[Sydney Airport|Mascot]] and [[RAAF Base Richmond|Richmond]], New South Wales, and [[RAAF Williams#RAAF Williams Point Cook Base|Point Cook]], Victoria, Gibbes was commissioned a [[pilot officer]] on 28 June 1940.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/people_60047.asp |title=Wing Commander Robert Henry Maxwell (Bobby) Gibbes, DSO, DFC and bar|publisher=[[Australian War Memorial]]|accessdate= 4 August 2013}} His initial posting was to [[No. 23 Squadron RAAF|No. 23 Squadron]], which operated [[CAC Wirraway]]s and [[Lockheed Hudson]]s out of [[RAAF Station Archerfield|Archerfield]], Queensland.Newton, ''Australian Air Aces'', p. 87RAAF Historical Section, ''Bomber Units'', pp. 69–70 He was promoted to [[flying officer]] on 26 December 1940. Two of Gibbes' cousins—both born in 1915 and, like Bobby, only sons—were also pilots in the RAAF.{{cite web|url=http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?serviceId=R&veteranId=1048296|title= Gibbes, Augustus Rodney|publisher=World War 2 Nominal Roll|accessdate= 6 August 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?serviceId=R&veteranId=1048298|title= Gibbes, Peter John|publisher=World War 2 Nominal Roll|accessdate= 6 August 2013}} Rodney Gibbes joined the Air Force in July 1936. Peter Gibbes, an airline pilot before the war, enlisted in December 1940. Each earned the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]], Rodney in 1940 for his part in a [[Vickers Wellington|Wellington]] bomber raid in Europe while serving with the [[Royal Air Force]], and Peter in 1942 for his actions flying a Hudson bomber with [[No. 1 Squadron RAAF]] during the [[Malayan Campaign]].{{LondonGazette|issue=34945|date=13 September 1940|startpage=5488|accessdate=on 6 August 2013}}{{LondonGazette|issue=35837|date=29 December 1942 |startpage=5638|supp=yes|accessdate=on 6 August 2013}} Rodney died in action over Italy on 16 May 1943.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/research/people/roll_of_honour/person.asp?p=554638|title=Augustus Rodney Gibbes|work=Roll of Honour|publisher=Australian War Memorial|accessdate=6 August 2013}} ==Combat service== ===Middle East=== [[File:008320No.3SquadronJun41.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Gibbes (front, left) with fellow pilots in the Middle East including John Jackson (back, left), June 1941. The next month, the pair shared an aerial victory whose credit went to Gibbes on the toss of a coin.|alt=Informal high-angled portrait of fourteen men in light-coloured military shorts and shirts, with a dog in the foreground]] In April 1941, Gibbes was posted to the Middle East as [[adjutant]] of [[No. 450 Squadron RAAF|No. 450 Squadron]].Gibbes; Stokes, "Gibbes, Robert Henry Maxwell 'Bobby'", p. 7 The following month he transferred to [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|No. 3 Squadron]], which was flying [[Hawker Hurricane]]s. In June, after converting to [[Curtiss P-40 variants|P-40 Tomahawks]], the squadron commenced operations in the [[Syria–Lebanon Campaign]].{{cite news|date=1 May 2007|title=Wing Commander Bobby Gibbes|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article1728384.ece|work=[[The Times]]|accessdate=26 October 2007 | location=London |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110523225908/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article1728384.ece|archivedate = 23 May 2011}} Gibbes was credited with a probable victory over a [[Junkers Ju 88]] near [[Bierut]] on 13 June.Thomas, ''Tomahawk and Kittyhawk Aces'', p. 8 On 11 July he claimed his first "kill", a [[Dewoitine D.520]] fighter of the [[Vichy France|Vichy French]] air force, over [[Aleppo]]. He shared in its destruction with [[John Francis Jackson|John Jackson]], after which the pair tossed a coin to take full credit for it, and Gibbes won. In September, No. 3 Squadron transferred to the [[Western Desert Campaign]], where it saw action against German and Italian forces.Thomas, ''Tomahawk and Kittyhawk Aces'', p. 9 On 20 November, during [[Operation Crusader]], Gibbes took part in the destruction of a [[Messerschmitt Bf 110]] with three other pilots, crash landing back at base with damage to his own aircraft.Shores; Williams, ''Aces High'', p. 161Shores; Ring, ''Fighters Over the Desert'', pp. 63–64 He had a particularly successful day on 25 November, when he shot down two [[Fiat G.50]]s and damaged three more, as well as a [[Messerschmitt Bf 109]]. Five days later he destroyed a G.50 over [[Tobruk]].Thomas, ''Tomahawk and Kittyhawk Aces'', p. 18 On 22 January 1942, he brought down a [[Junkers Ju 87]] and damaged two G.50s. He was promoted to acting [[flight lieutenant]] the same month. Raised to acting [[squadron leader]], Gibbes was appointed commanding officer of No. 3 Squadron on 26 February 1942. The unit's Tomahawks had by this time been replaced by Kittyhawks, and Gibbes emblazoned his with a cartoon depicting a [[kangaroo]] kicking a [[dachshund]] in the rear.{{cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/obituaries/wing-commander-robert-gibbes-1-743665|title=Wing-Commander Robert Gibbes|work=[[The Scotsman]]|date=18 April 2007|accessdate=18 September 2013}} He claimed a Bf 109 (possibly a misidentified [[Macchi C.202]]) during the [[Siege of Tobruk]] on 7 May.Thomas, ''Tomahawk and Kittyhawk Aces'', pp. 31–32 On 26 May, he was shot down while leading an attack on a heavily escorted force of ''[[Luftwaffe]]'' bombers near [[Gamal Abdul El Nasser Air Base|El Adem]]. After firing at and probably destroying a Bf 109, Gibbes was hit by fire from a Ju 88 and had to [[parachute|bail out]]. Part of his parachute became entangled with the tailplane of his stricken aircraft and he struggled to escape.Herington, [https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070683--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Germany and Italy'', pp. 231, 244] He broke his ankle in the landing but within six weeks was flying again, his leg still in a cast.{{cite news | date = 25 April 2007 | title = Wg Cdr Bobby Gibbes| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1549575/Wg-Cdr-Bobby-Gibbes.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]| accessdate=8 August 2013 | location=London| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121113102212/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1549575/Wg-Cdr-Bobby-Gibbes.html| archivedate=13 November 2012}} Due to his enforced absence, fellow ace [[Nicky Barr]] was given command of No. 3 Squadron until he himself was shot down and taken prisoner on 26 June, at which point Gibbes again took charge of the unit. Barr later said that although Gibbes was not a brilliant shot, he had the keenest eyesight of any pilot he knew when it came to locating enemy aircraft and alerting his fellows for the attack.Barr; Stokes, "Barr, Andrew William 'Nicky'", pp. 15–16 Another No. 3 Squadron pilot, Tom Russell, also recalled that Gibbes was particularly adept at finding targets, and that "if we got scattered in a dogfight he had the uncanny ability to get us back into formation in a very short space of time".Russell; Stokes, "Russell, Thomas Leslie", p. 17 [[File:Royal Air Force- Operations in the Middle East and North Africa, 1940-1943. CM3112.jpg|left|thumb|upright=1.2|Squadron Leader Gibbes as commanding officer of No. 3 Squadron, North Africa, shortly after being awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross in July 1942|alt=Informal head-and-shoulders portrait of grinning man in peaked cap surrounded by four others]] Gibbes was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross (DFC) on 28 July 1942 for his actions on 26 May, the citation noting his "exceptional skill and gallantry".{{LondonGazette|issue=35646|date=28 July 1942|startpage=3302|supp=yes|accessdate=on 16 November 2008}} On 1 September, he destroyed a Bf 109 and damaged two others during the [[Battle of Alam el Halfa]], east of [[El Alamein]].Shores; Ring, ''Fighters Over the Desert'', p. 169 He claimed No. 3 Squadron's 200th victim, a Bf 109F, during the [[Second Battle of El Alamein|Battle of El Alamein]] on 28 October.Thomas, ''Tomahawk and Kittyhawk Aces'', p. 43Shores; Ring, ''Fighters Over the Desert'', p. 197 Air Marshal [[Peter Roy Maxwell Drummond|Sir Peter Drummond]], Deputy Air Officer Commanding-in-Chief [[Middle East Command|Middle East]], sent him a signal reading "Heartiest congratulations to you and all ranks in the squadron on the achievement of your [[Century (cricket)|double century]]—[[not out]]".{{cite news |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/12003121 |title=Double century—not out |newspaper=[[The Argus (Australia)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=2 November 1942 |accessdate=18 September 2013 |page=12 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Around this time Gibbes also managed to fly Bf 109F and G fighters captured from the Germans, and came away impressed. He was credited with another Bf 109 on 17 November. On 21 December, he landed his Kittyhawk in rugged terrain near [[Hun, Libya|Hun]], Libya, to rescue a fellow pilot who had been forced down. Gibbes threw out his own parachute to make room in the [[cockpit]] for his passenger and lost part of his [[Landing gear|undercarriage]] taking off, necessitating a one-wheeled landing back at base.Wilson, ''The Brotherhood of Airmen'', pp. 88–89Thomas, ''Tomahawk and Kittyhawk Aces'', p. 45 Recommended for the [[Victoria Cross]] for this action, he was instead awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]], which was promulgated on 15 January 1943 and cited his "outstanding qualities of leadership and enthusiasm".{{LondonGazette|issue=35864|date=15 January 1943|startpage=330|supp=yes|accessdate=on 16 November 2008}} Gibbes himself crash landed behind enemy lines on 14 January 1943, walking {{convert|50|mi|km}} in the desert before being picked up by a British Army patrol.{{cite journal | last = Stackpool | first = Andrew | date = 3 May 2007 | title = WWII ace farewelled | url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4907/features/feature4.htm | journal = [[Air Force (newspaper)|Air Force News]] |accessdate = 26 October 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070914225800/http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4907/features/feature4.htm|archivedate=14 September 2007}} He was awarded a [[Medal bar|bar]] to his DFC for this feat, and for his "exceptional leadership, skill and courage, contributing in a large measure to the success of the squadron he commands".{{LondonGazette|issue=36027|date=25 May 1943|startpage=2319|supp=yes|accessdate=on 16 November 2008}} The award made him the most highly decorated pilot in the RAAF. On 22 January 1943, Gibbes claimed his last kill, a C.202. He was officially credited with a total of 10¼ victories,Odgers, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 125Dornan, ''Nicky Barr'', pp. 279–280 though other estimates gave him a score of 12, including two shared.Thomas, ''Tomahawk and Kittyhawk Aces'', p. 102 He was also credited with five "probables", and another 16 damaged. During his tour of duty in the Middle East, he flew 274 [[sortie]]s and became No. 3 Squadron's longest-serving wartime commanding officer. Squadron member Bob Smith recalled him as lacking somewhat in administrative ability, but an "[[Errol Flynn]]" in the air.Smith; Stokes, "Smith, Robert Bruce 'Bob'", p. 12 Gibbes, for his part, later admitted to being in "an absolute state of terror" before missions, only to "sort of become mechanical" once the shooting started.Gibbes; Stokes, "Gibbes, Robert Henry Maxwell 'Bobby'", p. 15 He described his post-combat feelings thus:{{cite web|last=Gibbes|first=Bobby|title=Bobby Gibbes writes on fear|url= http://www.3squadron.org.au/subpages/bgfear.htm | publisher=3 Sqn Association|accessdate=4 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502151227/http://www.3squadron.org.au/subpages/bgfear.htm|archivedate=2 May 2013}} {{quote|text=Man becomes animal when he thinks he is about to die. As you fly back to your base, now safe at last, a feeling of light-hearted exuberance comes over you. It is wonderful to still be alive and it is, I think, merely the after-effect of violent, terrible fear.}} ===South West Pacific=== [[File:Bobby Gibbes Spitfire on Morotai 1945 AWM OG2366.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Ground crew service Gibbes's Spitfire "Grey Nurse" on Morotai, Dutch East Indies, in 1945|alt=Two men sitting in and beside the cockpit, and another sitting astride the nose, of a military aircraft]] Gibbes handed over command of No. 3 Squadron to Squadron Leader [[Brian Eaton]] on 19 April 1943.RAAF Historical Section, ''Fighter Units'', p. 7 With his rank of squadron leader confirmed the same month, Gibbes departed North Africa to serve at [[RAAF Overseas Headquarters]], London, until October. While in England he converted to [[de Havilland Mosquito]] night fighters and was slated to command [[No. 464 Squadron RAAF]], but was instead posted back to Australia, via Canada. There, according to Gibbes, he gave a series of morale-building lectures on air combat to [[British Commonwealth Air Training Plan|Empire Air Training Scheme]] students: "So I, you know, went round and lied like hell. I said that it was all a [[wikt:piece of cake#Noun|piece of cake]]."Gibbes; Stokes, "Gibbes, Robert Henry Maxwell 'Bobby'", pp. 40–41 In January 1944, he joined [[No. 2 Operational Conversion Unit RAAF|No. 2 Operational Training Unit]] (OTU) at [[Mildura, Victoria|Mildura]], Victoria, becoming chief flying instructor in March. He worked with [[Clive Caldwell]], Australia's top-scoring ace, to improve the success rate at No. 2 OTU by personally selecting the most promising pilots from local service flying training schools.Alexander, ''Clive Caldwell'', pp. 139, 158 Gibbes was promoted to temporary [[Wing Commander (rank)|wing commander]] on 1 July. In October he was posted to [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]] in the Northern Territory, flying [[Supermarine Spitfire]]s as wing leader of [[No. 80 Wing RAAF|No. 80 Wing]].Alexander, ''Clive Caldwell'', pp. 166, 272 The role made him deputy to Group Captain Caldwell, the wing's commanding officer. Gibbes later suffered burns in a crash landing following engine failure. In December he met, in his own words, "a little dark-haired popsy" named Jeannine Ince, a volunteer with the [[Red Cross]] who had nursed him in hospital. They married on 23 January 1945. No. 80 Wing had begun transferring to the [[Dutch East Indies]] in December 1944, and the main body followed in January 1945. Gibbes' injuries prevented him from joining the formation at its base on [[Morotai]], where it came under the control of the [[Australian First Tactical Air Force]] (No. 1 TAF), until 9 March. Once there, he took over as temporary commanding officer for a few days when Caldwell was called to [[Manila]].Alexander, ''Clive Caldwell'', pp. 166–168, 178 In April, Gibbes was one of eight senior pilots, including Caldwell and fellow aces [[Wilfred Arthur|Wilf Arthur]] and [[John Lloyd Waddy|John Waddy]], who tendered their resignations in protest at the relegation of RAAF fighter squadrons to apparently worthless ground-attack missions. The incident became known as the "[[Morotai Mutiny]]".Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 123–124Odgers, [https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070400--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 443–445] Gibbes later declared that "... after I myself had been operating for a week or so and had a really good look around and seen the futility of the operations which had been given, I could not see any point in carrying on. I certainly lost all keenness for remaining in the service." As a former jackaroo, he was especially upset about one sortie that involved attacking cattle: "I felt horrible about it, being an ex [[The bush|bushy]] ... at about lunch time I went out and darned if I didn't have to turn butcher. And Heavens, it was butchering too, in every sense of the word. No—not the Japs. Cattle ... If we are to get the Japs out of this area without loss of human lives, starvation will be our main weapon ... God, I hated doing it but could do nothing else. Felt as sick as hell."{{cite journal|last= Alexander | first= Kristen |date = 1 September 2004 | title= "Cleaning the Augean stables". The Morotai Mutiny? | work=Sabretache | publisher= Military Historical Society of Australia | url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/%22Cleaning+the+augean+stables.%22+The+Morotai+Mutiny%3F-a0123162109|accessdate=2 May 2010}} No action was taken against the "mutineers" for their attempted resignations; a subsequent government inquiry found that their protest was justified. In the meantime, Gibbes and Caldwell were court martialled for their involvement in alcohol trafficking on Morotai. Both were reduced to the rank of flight lieutenant; the [[Air Officer Commanding]] No. 1 TAF, Air Commodore [[Harry Cobby]], himself shortly to be dismissed over the "mutiny", restored Gibbes to squadron leader effective 23 April.Alexander, ''Clive Caldwell'', pp. 202–203, 212{{cite news |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/27936301 |title=R. H. Gibbes reduced in rank to squadron leader |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |location=Sydney |date=1 June 1945 |accessdate=18 September 2013 |page=1 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} ==Post-war career and later life== [[File:NWA0707AGibbes1945.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.9|Wing Commander Gibbes with wife Jean in Darwin, 1945|alt=Informal full-length portrait of woman in skirt and blouse and man in light-coloured military uniform standing on steps in front of a building]] In July 1945, Gibbes was assigned to the staff of RAAF Headquarters, [[Melbourne]]. Following his discharge from the Air Force on 11 January 1946, he was initially employed as a stock and station agent in [[Coonamble, New South Wales|Coonamble]], New South Wales.Turner, ''The RAAF at War'', p. 162 He flew a Butler Bat twin-engined aircraft to facilitate his work, reportedly the only New South Welshman in his profession to do so at the time.{{cite news |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/48478795 |title=Bobby Gibbes in air with job |newspaper=[[The Barrier Miner]] |location=Broken Hill, New South Wales |date=17 September 1946 |accessdate=18 September 2013 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Gibbes spent much of the next 30 years in New Guinea, pioneering the island's transport, coffee and hospitality industries. In January 1948, he formed Gibbes Sepik Airways using, among other types, three German [[Junkers Ju 52]]s, one of which was said to have been the personal transport of senior ''[[Luftwaffe]]'' commander [[Albert Kesselring]]. He was joined briefly in this venture, headquartered at [[Wewak]], by Nicky Barr.Dornan, ''Nicky Barr'', p. 273 Gibbes also established a tea and coffee plantation at [[Mount Hagen]], New Guinea, in 1950, and served as a member of the RAAF Active Reserve, based in [[Townsville, Queensland|Townsville]], Queensland, from 1952 until 1957.Alexander, ''Who’s Who in Australia 1955'', p. 308 In 1958, he sold his share in Gibbes Sepik Airways to Mandated Airlines, which was later bought out by [[Ansett Australia]]. He continued to develop coffee plantations in New Guinea, and built a large chain of hotels beginning with the Bird of Paradise in [[Goroka]]. Gibbes sold his interests in New Guinea in 1972. He spent most of the remainder of the decade in the Mediterranean, aboard his [[catamaran]] ''Billabong''. In his 60s, he sailed ''Billabong'' from England to Australia by himself, braving heavy seas and Malaysian pirates along the way. By 1979 he was living in Sydney and had begun building his own twin-engined plane, which he eventually took to the air in 1990. In 1994, Gibbes published his autobiography, ''You Live But Once''. He continued to fly until forced to give up his [[civil aviation]] licence at the age of 85. In 2002, he appeared in an episode of the television series ''[[Australian Story]]'' dedicated to Nicky Barr.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/austory/transcripts/s513633.htm |title=The Quiet Man|work=[[Australian Story]]|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date= 1 April 2002|accessdate=4 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020817101037/http://www.abc.net.au/austory/transcripts/s513633.htm|archivedate=17 August 2002}} Gibbes was awarded the [[Medal of the Order of Australia]] on [[Australia Day|26 January]] 2004 for "service to aviation and to tourism, particularly in Papua New Guinea".{{cite web|url=http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1056229&search_type=quick&showInd=true|title=Gibbes, Robert Henry: Medal of the Order of Australia|publisher=[[It's an Honour]]|date=26 January 2004|accessdate=4 August 2013}} He died of a stroke at [[Mona Vale Hospital]] in Sydney on 11 April 2007, aged 90, and was survived by his wife and two daughters. His funeral service at St Thomas' Church, [[North Sydney, New South Wales|North Sydney]], was attended by 350 mourners, including the [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of Air Force]], Air Marshal [[Geoff Shepherd]], and 40 members of No. 3 Squadron led by the commanding officer. A Spitfire in the "[[Grey nurse shark|Grey Nurse]]" [[livery]] of one of Gibbes' World War II aircraft overflew the church, along with four [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet|F/A-18 Hornet]] jet fighters from No. 3 Squadron in a "[[Missing man formation|missing man]]" formation.{{cite news | date = 17 April 2007 | title = WWII veteran Bobby Gibbes farewelled by Spitfire | url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2007-04-17/wwii-veteran-bobby-gibbes-farewelled-by-spitfire/2244798 | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | accessdate = 10 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120908221039/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2007-04-17/wwii-veteran-bobby-gibbes-farewelled-by-spitfire/2244798|archivedate=8 September 2012}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== * {{cite book|last=Alexander |first=Joseph A.
